Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: Methodology for Applying Haptic Robotics to Agile Manufacturing
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase-II research project addresses safety, user -interface, and performance challenges uncovered in Phase I while adapting a haptic robot to the manufacturing environment for medium-production-run paint spraying. Haptics is an exciting field, but industry adoption has been slow. Yet without haptics in applications like medium-run paint spraying, the two alternatives (fully automated or fully manual) are unappealing. Robots are prohibitively expensive to program for short runs, and fully manual operations endanger worker health.

The technologically revolutionary haptics field has not yet revolutionized manufacturing. Some manufacturing tasks lack good alternatives, especially in medium run production, where one must choose between high-cost, time-consuming robot programming versus poor worker health. Physical robot-craftsperson interaction will benefit these middle applications, if safe and intuitive.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II and IIB project introduced a novel and general methodology for applying highly backdrivable robots and haptics (force-feedback) in agile, small-production-run manufacturing. Barrett Technology has been a leader in safer robots and this project has enabled Barrett to leverage its technology in the emerging field of collaborative robotics – where a robotic system operates with enhanced safety in concert with skilled workers to increase production, allow for better in-line quality control, and enable flexible manufacturing.

Through this project, Barrett Technology introduced three new products, including its two flagship products the 7-axis WAM Arm and BarrettHand 280, along with a compact 6-axis Force/Torque Sensor. Barrett developed a more integrated and robust control package and library, libbarrett, that enhances safety, enables various customer-control methods, allows for complex force projections and haptic feedback, and improves communication efficiencies. These new systems and software enable a paradigm shift from the robot as a dangerous and complex piece of segregated machinery, to a portable workcell tool that becomes an extension of the technician rather than a replacement for the technician.

Barrett also employed 13 high-school and college students as interns performing challenging and useful engineering work in the engaging field of robotics.
